title: Kung Pow! Enter the Fist
descriptions:
Kung Pow! Enter the Fist (2002) is a slapstick martial arts comedy that parodies classic kung fu films by blending new footage with a 1976 Hong Kong movie, Tiger and Crane Fists. Writer-director-star Steve Oedekerk digitally inserts himself into the old film as “The Chosen One,” a baby who survives an attack by the tyrannical Master Pain—later rebranding himself as “Betty”—and grows up determined to avenge his family.

As an infant, The Chosen One displays absurd superhuman abilities, rolling away from danger and besting adult attackers. Years later, now a wandering fighter, he follows rumors of his destiny and confronts various henchmen, including a persistent two-headed adversary and a set of hilariously inept villains. He eventually arrives at a rural village, where he meets Master Tang, a comically decrepit martial arts teacher whose students include the loyal Ling and the timid Wimp Lo. Tang claims to sense The Chosen One’s special chi, but his teachings are farcical, framed by nonsensical drills and exaggerated injuries.

The Chosen One learns that Master Pain/Betty is terrorizing the region, shaking down villages and wielding powerful kung fu. Betty is both ridiculous and dangerous, mixing flamboyant line deliveries with ruthless tactics. He murders Master Tang’s students and makes examples of resisters, all while denying his own identity with a running gag about his name change. The Chosen One’s encounters with him escalate from skirmishes to full-blown set pieces, laced with intentionally mismatched dubbing, cartoonish sound effects, and visual gags like obvious CG animals and exaggerated wire work.

Guided by signs of destiny—including an ancient prophecy and the intervention of tongue-in-cheek mystical forces—The Chosen One trains and faces surreal challenges. One of the film’s most memorable bits involves a telepathic fight with a talkative, breakdancing cow, which ends in a Matrix-style bullet-time spoof and udders used as projectile weapons. Elsewhere, The Chosen One deciphers clues about a mark on his tongue that signifies his prophesied role: only he can defeat Betty and the ultimate evil he serves.

Romantic and comedic subplots run through the training sequences. Ling develops affection for The Chosen One, offering support and earnest pep talks, while Wimp Lo provides a steady stream of misinterpreted martial arts wisdom and bungled bravado. Master Tang alternates between dubious encouragement and fatalistic humor, often at odds with his own well-being. The movie’s humor leans into overdubbing jokes, purposefully mis-timed dialogue, and deliberate continuity errors, poking fun at kung fu dubbing traditions and low-budget filmmaking.

As the stakes rise, The Chosen One learns that Betty is connected to a greater threat embodied by the evil “Evil Council” and a mysterious artifact. The Chosen One’s tongue symbol ties him to a legendary power that can either save or doom the world. After further training and bizarre visions—including a prophetic encounter with a talking, wisecracking tongue and floating spiritual guides—he confronts Betty again. Their clashes play like affectionate genre spoofs infused with cartoon logic: gravity-defying flips, palm strikes that send foes flying, and deathblows treated like punchlines.

The final act pushes the parody to its peak. The Chosen One battles his way through Betty’s forces and faces the villain’s enhanced form, revealing Betty’s connection to an alien-like menace known as the Evil Council’s ultimate weapon. Channeling his destiny, The Chosen One accesses hidden chi abilities. He unleashes impossibly powerful moves, including the “Gopher Chucks” gag and energy-laden strikes that outdo Betty’s own techniques. With Ling’s encouragement and the memory of his slain family, he overcomes Betty in a climactic showdown that balances mock-epic spectacle with deliberately cheesy effects.

In the aftermath, the village celebrates, but The Chosen One’s journey isn’t entirely over. The film teases that even greater enemies remain, as hinted by a final stinger involving the Evil Council. The Chosen One strides off with Ling and his allies, buoyed by victory and still wrapped in the movie’s freewheeling absurdity.

Overall, Kung Pow! Enter the Fist operates as a collage comedy: a mix of old-school kung fu footage, new scenes, and heavy redubbing to create a new narrative. Its plot follows a standard revenge-and-destiny arc, but the storytelling serves primarily as a framework for relentless, juvenile, and meta humor—visual puns, slapstick, fourth-wall breaks, and genre pastiche. The result is a parody that both lampoons and pays homage to the martial arts films it imitates, anchored by The Chosen One’s quest to defeat Betty and fulfill his prophecy through the most ridiculous means possible.
